title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Libya before 1 January 2017?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Unfortunately, the tribes won't find a common ground but ISIS will find its solid evil ground. But the chance is not too high. It might be an unsettling move by ISIS for Christmas.
Remember that "mass killing" is operationalized in this case as at least *one thousand* put to death en masse as part of a group.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
October update: Crisis Watch lists low numbers for Aug., Sept., and Oct.  Most violence is military / militia related.
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-38049950. This could continue until or beyond January 1st, 2017 along with the possibility of clashes between other clans.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Short time frame and a more or less stable situation in Libya.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Leaked Tapes of US support for Haftar indicating a shift away from UN reconciliation strategy. Someone will make a move before Trump's inauguration.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

According to ACLED, "Libya is entering into a transition stage in which splintered political groups are beginning to coalesce, shifting the balance of power back towards a bipolar conflict system." http://www.crisis.acleddata.com/conflict-stabilisation-in-libya/
Meanwhile, the failed nation is only experiencing 40-60 fatalities per month (!) so a low forecast seems right for what's left of 2016.
As for 2017, I'm not so sure. A complete economic collapse appears likely ( https://www.rt.com/business/364945-world-bank-libya-economic-collapse/ ) and what's left of ISIS might see Libya as a vulnerable and attractive alternative to Syria.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Libya is more stable and there is less violent fighting this year.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Currently the US is conducting airstrikes and holding an interest in the region. As a result the pressure to keep civilian causalities down is paramount. Additionally, ISIS does not have the resources to carry out an attack as they are trying to hold territory.
According to the News, libya is figthing against Isis, but with the intervention of Usa and libyan forces i think that we don't expect any probability of a mass killing.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
2.5 months to go.  Nothing seems to be brewing. Chance of trigger event tho that could kick things off.

I don't think it's quite 0 but nearly all the violence seems to be targeted at combatants (military/militias/IS etc), so would take a massive change of circumstances for such a high death rate to be reached and there are few signs of such a targeted campaign from any side.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Less likely for this to happen it seems.

152 people killed in acts of violence against civilians, by all actors, in Libya so far in 2016 (as of September 24) according to ACLED.  That makes 1,000 by December 31st by one actor highly unlikely.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Things are getting better over there.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Crisis watch not reporting anything close to a positive resolution.
Due to consensus and EWP definition.

"At least 600 civilians were killed in 2015 according to the ICC Prosecutor."
https://www.amnesty.org/en/countries/middle-east-and-north-africa/libya/report-libya/

As per Darin's comment, existing casualty figures unlikely to hit the 1000 threshold by 1 Jan 2017.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/313675

41 civilian casualties in July, an uptick in violence required to reach 1,000
http://unsmil.unmissions.org/Default.aspx?tabid=3543&ctl=Details&mid=6187&Itemid=2099677&language=en-US
I probably misunderstood the question in my previous 2 forecasts
I see it as one of the most likely ISISÂ´s reaction to its forced retreat caused by the Libyan militia

I'm following Sjens' commentary on this and also believe it not likely for a deliberate mass killing of 1000 people. Though that number by definition occurs over a 12 month period. I don't believe it will reach that number January 1st.

271 violent deaths in Libya up to February 
https://www.libyaherald.com/2016/04/11/271-violent-deaths-in-libya-up-to-february/

Unfortunately with ISIS losing ground in Libya it can be reasonably expected that they will resort to mass killings.   Once the more conventional way of fighting is not an option for them then the suicide bombings and killing of captured civilians becomes the mode of operation.

I am not completely up to date on this and may correct my forecast later.
The UN-brokered unity government  kind of seems to work for now - for the first time? And more importantly, the IS is finally getting defeated in Sirte right now. At the beginning of the year, I would have forecasted this with 15-20%. Now I am only in with 3%, since I do not believe that the IS will have the capabilities to kill 1.000+ civilians deliberately and I assume that the UN is watching the (still competing) two parliaments and local governments close enough to at least avoid a massive bloodshed on this scale.
